byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Hana de Goeij in Prague; Palko Karasz in Budapest; Miroslava Germanova in Bratislava, Slovakia; Richard Martyn-Hemphill in Riga, Latvia; Kit Gillet in Bucharest, Romania; and Joanna Berendt in Warsaw.

abstract: Poland, Czech Republic and Romania consent to European Union’s refugee relocation plan, despite vigorous opposition in their countries; proposal, passed by vote instead of consensus due to strong backlash, asks prosperous Western member-nations to take most of 120,000 refugees but requests less wealthier members take some out of solidarity.
lead_paragraph: Only Slovakia continued to promise a full-on fight after the European Union approved the plan, though the acquiescence of other countries in Central and Eastern Europe may anger voters.

headline.main: Opposition to Refugee Quotas Softens in Europe’s Old Communist Bloc
headline.print_headline: Europe’s Old Communist Bloc Softens Opposition to Refugee Quotas

snippet: Only Slovakia continued to promise a full-on fight after the European Union approved the plan, though the acquiescence of other countries in Central and Eastern Europe may anger voters.
